Response: NA; we didn't have any changes

This participating ACH has slowly adopted the following practice changes through  an  engaged Clinician group. 1. Utilizing the working DRG list to identify BPCIA patients during the anchor stay; 2. Utilizing a scoring tool to offer guidance in most effective first place destination; 3. Reviewing BPCIA discharge destination data to drive better performance 4. Dedicating case managers to follow impatients without known existing case management during the post- acute episode.

This ACH is a slow adopter for change greatly due to an independent culture that has long sustained high IRF and SNF utilization for Medicare patients. In addition, the geographical footprint in that area does not support a high volume of Geisinger employed physicians/case managers.
NA; we are a Non-Convener Participant
We are not a convener participant and we have not yet  used gain sharing agreements with other entities.
NA; never participated in financial arrangements
NA; we don't participate in NPRA Sharing

Geisinger's compensation plan does not allow for sharing with individual Physicians or PGPs; During BPCI Classic program, the Geisinger system did engage in an EIP NPRA gain sharing program that was complex and time consuming with administrative costs. We also found that only about 1/3 of BPCI Classic beneficiaries chose a partnering EIP. Therefor we have chosen not to gain share with EIPS at this time.
NA; we don't participate in NPRA Sharing
NA; we don't have relationship with a BPCI Advanced Entity

We had limited success with an EIP gain sharing program in BPCI Classic. We continue to explore how we might do so again if we can find a reliable means to identify BPCIA beneficiaries who qualify for the program during the anchor stay.
NA; not requiring shared repayments by partners

Point of clarification: We opted for use of waivers at beginning of the program but have not used any to date; We have a participating ACO that uses the SNF waiver and found it too confusing to use both- Until we find a reliable means to identify the BPCIA beneficiary during the anchor stay, we will not be using the waivers. Additionally, our limited ability to reliable identify BPCIA beneficiaries during the anchor stay has caused our cautious approach.

The Geisinger system Population Health Service line administrates the BPCIA program. IF any of the staff exit the SL, the next level of management will determine the replacement(s). All records are kept in a Share-point file.
We rely on the compliance plan processes in place to assist us in identifying any related issues. We had this compliance in place during BPCI classic and now with the Advanced model years as well.

We are participating in the ACO program which causes redundancy and at times some confusion. For example, the ACO qualifies the system as an APM and is required to submit signed documents by Providers related to QPP. Now we must do the same for BPCIA. Also, the SNF waiver process has been very different and since we establish that at least half of the Bundles beneficiaries are also tied to ACO we have elected not to use the waiver.
